It is rea· mallentin. eonable to suppose that this essential of monastic order was strictly observed in the Columbian system. Hence the readiness of thc brethren to prepare 011 the shortest notice for a long and wearisome journey (60), or a distant and hazardous voyage (47, 109, 1 1 1, 155), or to do the service of the monastery (106), or to submit to exposure 111 out-door work, at the local Superior's desire, during the most inc-lenient weather (57), or to undertake an office of responsibility, though by a nephew’s order (86). Hence the acquiescence in an injunction to intemiit a custom (217), and the severe rebuke which attended a violation of his command (218, 226). The obedientia eine mora of the Benedictine Rule' was evidenced in Hy by the alacrity with which the abbot’s orders were executed (91 ‚ 112, 125), and the speed with which a distant bro- ther forsook the church of his sojourn, and hastened, at the abbot's call, to Hy, there to abide in ‘cera obedientia (60).
